content.question: Which of the following is often true about semi-presidential systems?

choices.label: The president is normally not very strong and has no constitutional powers, which makes the prime minister more powerful in policy making.
The prime minister usually controls foreign policy, which means the president focuses strictly on the domestic economy.
Semi-presidential systems almost always have devolved unitary systems, which frequently results in a divided government.
The president usually nominates the prime minister, which implies that the prime minister would support the president’s policy agenda.

content.answer: The president usually nominates the prime minister, which implies that the prime minister would support the president’s policy agenda.
